/p/.student: Press your lips together and release a small puff of air — like a quick “puh.” Feel the air on your hand.
/p/.teacher: Focus on lip closure and aspiration. Use minimal pairs like pat vs bat. Try tissue-blowing exercises to visualize airflow.
/p/.parent: Help your child press their lips and blow gently. Hold a tissue in front of their mouth to see it flutter when they say “puh.”

/b/.student: Press your lips together and say “buh” using your voice. Feel the buzz in your throat.
/b/.teacher: Contrast with /b/ to teach voicing. Use tactile feedback — place fingers on the throat to feel vibration.
/b/.parent: Say “buh” and let your child touch your throat to feel the buzz. Then have them try it themselves.

/t/.student: Tap your tongue behind your upper teeth and say “tuh.” It’s a quick, light sound.
/t/.teacher: Reinforce tongue-tip contact at the alveolar ridge. Use mirror practice and CVC words like top, tap.
/t/.parent: Help your child tap their tongue near their teeth. Use a mirror to show where the tongue goes.

/d/.student: Touch your tongue behind your teeth and say “duh” with your voice. Feel the vibration.
/d/.teacher: Contrast with /t/. Use voiced plosive drills and mirror feedback. Try minimal pairs like dog vs tog.
/d/.parent: Say “duh” and let your child feel the throat buzz. Use a mirror to show tongue placement.

/g/.student: Say “guh” by raising the back of your tongue and using your voice. Feel the buzz.
/g/.teacher: Focus on voiced velars. Use contrasts like go vs coat. Use throat-touch feedback.
/g/.parent: Say “guh” and let your child feel the vibration in their throat. Practice with words like go, gum.

/tʃ/.student: Make a “ch” sound by stopping the air with your tongue then releasing it — like “chuh.”
/tʃ/.teacher: Teach affricate as stop + fricative. Use words like chew, chalk. Use train sound “ch-ch-ch” for fun.
/tʃ/.parent: Practice “ch” by pretending to be a train — “ch-ch-ch!” Make it playful and rhythmic.

/dʒ/.student: Say “juh” by stopping the air and releasing it with your voice. Feel the buzz.
/dʒ/.teacher: Reinforce voiced affricate production. Contrast with /tʃ/: jar vs char. Use mirror and tactile cues.
/dʒ/.parent: Say “juh” slowly and let your child feel the vibration. Use words like jam, jump.

/f/.student: Gently bite your bottom lip and blow air out — say “ffff.”
/f/.teacher: Emphasize lip-teeth contact and airflow. Use mirrors and initial sound drills.
/f/.parent: Show your child how to bite their lip and blow. Use a feather or tissue to show the air movement.

/v/.student: Bite your bottom lip and use your voice — say “vuh.” Feel the buzz.
/v/.teacher: Contrast with /f/. Use tactile vibration exercises and minimal pairs like fan vs van.
/v/.parent: Say “vuh” and let your child feel the buzzing in their lips and throat. Try “v-v-v” like a buzzing bee.

/θ/.student: Put your tongue between your teeth and blow — like “th” in think.
/θ/.teacher: Use mirror for interdental placement. Contrast with /s/ or /t/. Practice with slow airflow.
/θ/.parent: Help your child stick their tongue out a little and blow gently. Use a mirror to guide placement.

/ð/.student: Put your tongue between your teeth and use your voice — say “th” like in this.
/ð/.teacher: Practice voiced dental fricatives with sustained phonation drills. Contrast with /θ/.
/ð/.parent: Say “th” with your child and feel the voice buzz through the tongue. Try words like that, them.

/s/.student: Make a long "sss" sound by letting air pass between your tongue and teeth without using your voice.
/s/.teacher: Focus on tongue positioning near the alveolar ridge and airflow. Use minimal pairs like "sip" vs "zip".
/s/.parent: Help your child say “sss” like a snake, with no voice, just air through the teeth.

/z/.student: Make a buzzing "zzz" sound with your tongue near your teeth while using your voice.
/z/.teacher: Contrast with /s/. Use tactile techniques to highlight vocal cord vibration.
/z/.parent: Say “zzz” together and feel the buzzing in your throat while holding the sound.

/ʃ/.student: Round your lips slightly and make a soft “shhh” sound like you’re asking someone to be quiet.
/ʃ/.teacher: Use whisper drills and contrast with /s/. Visual prompts and audio modeling help.
/ʃ/.parent: Make a fun “shhh” sound together like quieting a room. Use hand gestures for fun reinforcement.

/ʒ/.student: Say a smooth buzzing sound like the middle of “measure” — lips rounded, air flows with voice.
/ʒ/.teacher: Emphasize voiced frication behind alveolar ridge. Use repetition and isolation.
/ʒ/.parent: This one’s tricky — say a gentle “zhhh” sound together and feel the buzz in your throat.

/h/.student: Gently breathe out as if you’re fogging up a mirror — that’s the “h” sound.
/h/.teacher: Reinforce gentle glottal airflow. Combine with vowel onsets like “ha, he, hi.”
/h/.parent: Have your child pretend to blow warm air on their hand — “hhh” like hot.

/m/.student: Close your lips and hum gently through your nose to make the “mmm” sound.
/m/.teacher: Use nasal vibration awareness and bilabial drills. Practice in CVC words.
/m/.parent: Say “mmm” like something tasty. Your child should feel a tickle in their nose.

/n/.student: Touch your tongue behind your teeth and hum through your nose — like “nnn.”
/n/.teacher: Focus on alveolar nasal articulation. Use contrastive drills with /d/ or /t/.
/n/.parent: Say “nnn” slowly and encourage your child to feel the buzz in their nose.

/ŋ/.student: Push the back of your tongue up to make the “ng” sound — like the end of “sing.”
/ŋ/.teacher: Practice final velar nasal articulation. Use phoneme segmentation drills.
/ŋ/.parent: Say “nggg” with your child — remind them not to let the air out their mouth.

/l/.student: Touch your tongue to the spot behind your top teeth and let air flow around the sides — say “lll.”
/l/.teacher: Emphasize lateral airflow and tongue-tip contact. Use mirror cues and repetition.
/l/.parent: Practice “llll” together. Use tongue-tip contact behind teeth to guide them.

/r/.student: Curl the tip of your tongue slightly up without touching the roof of your mouth — say “rrr.”
/r/.teacher: Focus on retroflex vs bunched articulations. Avoid lateralization.
/r/.parent: This can be tricky. Say “rrr” like a growl together and feel the vibration.

/ɹ/.student: Curl the tip of your tongue slightly up without touching the roof of your mouth — say “rrr.”
/ɹ/.teacher: Focus on retroflex vs bunched articulations. Avoid lateralization.
/ɹ/.parent: This can be tricky. Say “rrr” like a growl together and feel the vibration.

/j/.student: Say “yuh” by gliding your tongue up toward the roof of your mouth near the front.
/j/.teacher: Use glide onset practice with vowels (e.g., yes, you). Emphasize tongue elevation.
/j/.parent: Say “yuh” like in “yes” together, moving from quiet to louder for practice.

/w/.student: Round your lips and say “wuh” while pushing air out with your voice.
/w/.teacher: Emphasize rounded lips and gliding motion. Use vocalic onset drills.
/w/.parent: Show your child how to round their lips and say “wuh” like blowing a kiss with sound.

/k/.student: Lift the back of your tongue to the roof of your mouth and release — say “kuh.”
/k/.teacher: Practice velar articulation with visual and kinesthetic cues. Use words like kick, cat.
/k/.parent: Help your child say “kuh” by lifting the back of their tongue. Try saying it while pretending to cough gently.

/ʔ/.student: This is a catch in your throat — like the break in “uh-oh.” Gently stop and start the air.
/ʔ/.teacher: Practice glottal stops with awareness of throat closure. Use contrast with vowel onsets.
/ʔ/.parent: Say “uh-oh” with your child. Point out the tiny pause in the middle.

/iː/.student: Smile wide and stretch the sound — say a long “eeee” like you're smiling in a photo.
/iː/.teacher: Reinforce tense vowel positioning and sustained phonation. Contrast with /ɪ/ using minimal pairs like seat vs sit.
/iː/.parent: Encourage your child to smile and say a long “eeee” sound. Use a mirror to show the smile shape.

/ɪ/.student: Say a short “ih” sound with a relaxed mouth — quick and soft.
/ɪ/.teacher: Contrast with /iː/. Use vowel length discrimination and minimal pairs like bit vs beet.
/ɪ/.parent: Help your child say a short “ih” sound. Keep it light and relaxed — no smiling needed.

/e/.student: Say “eh” with your mouth slightly open and your tongue forward — like in bed.
/e/.teacher: Practice mid front vowel with vowel maps and /e/-/æ/ contrasts. Use visual cues.
/e/.parent: Show your child how to say a flat “eh” sound — not too wide or narrow.

/æ/.student: Open your mouth wide and say “aah” like you're surprised — short and clear.
/æ/.teacher: Focus on low front tongue placement and open jaw. Use contrasts with /e/ and words like cat vs ket.
/æ/.parent: Say a wide “aah” together and exaggerate the mouth shape. Use playful expressions.

/ɑː/.student: Drop your jaw low and say “ahh” deep in your throat — hold it long and steady.
/ɑː/.teacher: Teach open back tongue placement. Use long vowel contrast drills like car vs cut.
/ɑː/.parent: Help your child say a low, long “ahh” — like at the doctor’s office. Use a mirror to show jaw drop.

/ʌ/.student: Say “uh” with a relaxed mouth and neutral tongue — short and low.
/ʌ/.teacher: Focus on central stressed vowel production. Contrast with /ə/ and /ɑː/.
/ʌ/.parent: Practice a short, relaxed “uh” with your child. Use words like cup, mud.

/ɒ/.student: Round your lips and drop your jaw slightly to say “aw” — short and deep.
/ɒ/.teacher: Reinforce rounded lip posture and open back tongue. Contrast with /ɔː/.
/ɒ/.parent: Say a quick, soft “aw” together while making round lips. Use words like hot, cot.

/ɔː/.student: Round your lips and make a long “awww” sound — like you're admiring something.
/ɔː/.teacher: Emphasize duration and lip rounding. Use minimal pairs like caught vs cot.
/ɔː/.parent: Practice a long “awww” sound while rounding lips — like blowing a kiss with sound.

/ʊ/.student: Say a short “uh” sound with rounded lips — quick and soft.
/ʊ/.teacher: Focus on tongue height and lip rounding. Contrast with /uː/ using pairs like book vs boot.
/ʊ/.parent: Help your child say a short “uh” sound with slightly rounded lips. Use words like foot, look.

/uː/.student: Say a long “ooo” by rounding your lips tightly and holding the sound.
/uː/.teacher: Practice prolonged back rounded vowels. Use /ʊ/ vs /uː/ contrasts like pool vs pull.
/uː/.parent: Say a long “ooo” together — like blowing a sound through a straw. Use words like moon, spoon.

/ə/.student: Make a soft “uh” sound — very quick and gentle, like a whisper.
/ə/.teacher: Practice schwa in unstressed syllables. Use clapping or stress marking in multisyllabic words.
/ə/.parent: Practice quick and soft “uh” sounds in short words like banana, sofa. Keep it light and relaxed.

/ɜː/.student: Say a long “err” sound in the middle of your mouth — steady and smooth.
/ɜː/.teacher: Teach mid central vowel with prolonged phonation. Contrast with /ə/ in stressed vs unstressed syllables.
/ɜː/.parent: Say “errr” slowly with your child and help them keep the sound even. Use words like bird, turn.

/eɪ/.student: Start with a short “eh” and glide into a smiling “ee” — one smooth, connected sound.
/eɪ/.teacher: Practice gliding from /e/ to /ɪ/. Use minimal pairs like bed vs bade to highlight the shift.
/eɪ/.parent: Say “eh–ee” slowly with your child. Use a mirror to show the smile forming at the end.

/aɪ/.student: Begin with a wide “ah” and glide up into a sharp “ee” — like climbing a hill with your voice.
/aɪ/.teacher: Emphasize open mouth at the start and rising tongue movement. Contrast with /eɪ/ and /ɔɪ/.
/aɪ/.parent: Say “ah-ee” together slowly. Use hand motions to show the rising pitch and movement.

/ɔɪ/.student: Round your lips for “aw” and slide into a quick “ee” — like turning a corner with your voice.
/ɔɪ/.teacher: Highlight the shift from rounded back to front close. Use contrasts like boy vs buy.
/ɔɪ/.parent: Practice “aw-ee” slowly. Show how the lips start round and end in a smile.

/aʊ/.student: Say “ah” and glide into a rounded “oo” — feel your mouth move from open to round.
/aʊ/.teacher: Teach front open to back rounded transition. Use visual diagrams and tactile cues.
/aʊ/.parent: Try “ah-oo” slowly with your child. Use a mirror to show the lip rounding at the end.

/əʊ/.student: Start with a soft “uh” and glide into a rounded “oo” — keep it smooth and flowing.
/əʊ/.teacher: Contrast with /ə/ and /uː/. Use mirror work to show lip rounding and tongue movement.
/əʊ/.parent: Say “uh–oo” slowly. Help your child round their lips at the end like blowing a bubble.

/ɪə/.student: Start with “ih” and glide gently to “uh” — like sliding down a soft slope.
/ɪə/.teacher: Teach front-close to mid-central transition. Use vowel contour maps and slow repetition.
/ɪə/.parent: Say “ih–uh” slowly with your child. Keep the sound gentle and connected.

/eə/.student: Say “eh” and slide into a soft “uh” — one smooth breathy sound.
/eə/.teacher: Emphasize mid-front to mid-central glide. Use elongation and stress placement in practice.
/eə/.parent: Say “eh–uh” slowly. Help your child keep the sound soft and flowing.

/ʊə/.student: Start with a rounded “oo” and glide into “uh” — relax your lips at the end.
/ʊə/.teacher: Practice rounded-to-central glides. Use mirror feedback and minimal pairs like poor vs paw.
/ʊə/.parent: Say “oo–uh” slowly. Show how the lips start rounded and relax at the end.
